isis.stitle: REPAIR INSTRUCTIONS FOR FIBERGLASS AND PLASTIC (ABS) MATERIAL - FIBERGLASS - SAFETY PRECAUTIONS

note.para: Observe the following when making repairs with fiberglass:

para.emph: Avoid spilling the resin or hardener on skin or clothing. If this occurs, remove with paint thinner or denatured alcohol. Then wash with soap and water. If the mixture contacts the eyes, flush thoroughly with water immediately. Continue flushing for at least 15 minutes and contact a physician as soon as possible.
In some cases, some individuals may have skin sensitivity to the use of these materials. Because of this, protective creams can be applied to the hands to guard against irritation.
When protective creams are not available, rubber gloves may be used to protect the hands. The gloves can be removed quickly leaving the hands clean for other work.

When working with fiberglass, always work in a well ventilated area. DO NOT SMOKE OR EXPOSE FLAME WHERE KITS ARE BEING USED OR STORED. If possible, obtain a kit of material large enough to accommodate only one or two jobs to avoid storing any quantity of the material. Resin liquid must be kept in a metal container or cabinet when not being used.
Repairs must be ground or sanded to match surrounding contours. When grinding or sanding, use approved safety equipment.

warning.para: FIBERGLASS ABS PLASTIC REPAIRS To avoid breathing dust and fumes, wear approved protective equipment. Breathing fiberglass ABS plastic dust and/or fumes can be hazardous to your health.

para.emph: 1. OSHA standards should be consulted with respect to mandatory requirements as well as suggested procedures to minimize exposure. (Reference: Title 29, Code of Federal Regulations, Section 1910, 1001.)
2. Whenever possible work on fiberglass and ABS plastics in a separate area away from other operations.
3. Always wear a respirator approved by NIOSH or MSHA during all fiberglass or ABS plastic repairs.
4. Worker clean-up. Wash your hands before eating, drinking or smoking.

warning.para: Fiberglass repairs are as safe as any other shop repairs, provided you take the proper precautions. The following items should be particularly noted:

para.emph: 1. Before using any materials, read the manufacturer's instructions.
2. Be sure work room is adequately ventilated. Prolonged exposure to resin fumes is irritating to skin and eyes.
3. Protect your eyes, face, and body from the fine dust that develops during grinding and sanding operations. Wear goggles, respirator mask and protective clothing.
4. Do not rub your face or eyes when working with fiberglass.
